Honestly, as far as video game movies go, Hitman is honestly just there. It doesn't do anything remarkably well or remarkably poor, it's just, at its core, a movie that exists. Timothy Olyphant does deliver a good performance (I didn't see bald Olyphant, I saw Agent 47), the action's fine and while there isn't a heavy emphasis on stealth, there is at least an in-story justification that there are people actively gunning for him. Can't say I cared much for the film's attempts to ship 47 with Olga Kurylenko. It felt rather silly seeing how a professional assassin like him does not strike me as the kind of guy in search of a girlfriend. Even without taking the source material into account, this didn't sit right with me. Of course, there are other absurd moments such as Desmond from Lost conveniently leaving the firearms loaded for 47 and a fight scene against his fellow hitmen that's never brought up again. But on the whole, Hitman is just another action movie that felt to me like it was gunning for the 24/Bourne crowd that only stands out because of the IP it's adapting. I wonder if the 2015 reboot is as absurdly bad as fans of the game say it is. Guess I'll find out soon enough. Why they kept this film's screenwriter for that film, especially since it was following the cinematic disaster that was Die Hard 5 (script penned by the same guy), is a mystery to me.

The movie gives life to the game ''Hitman: Codename 47'' one of the best stealth video games ever made by IO Interactive and published by Eidos Interactive for Microsoft Windows in November 2000. 
The movie has some great action scenes and nice visual effects. Unfortunately, there are a lot of negatives, including a weak plot, unnecessary dialogs and mostly missing the game vibes. 
It's a movie worth watching.
Guilty pleasure. But Timothy did his part.
